p._value:
openssl-ts -
Time Stamping Authority command

_values:
This command is
a basic Time Stamping Authority (

)
client and server application as specified in

deployment and its role is to provide long term proof of the
existence of a certain datum before a particular time. Here
is a brief description of the protocol:

encoded protocol data unit defined for
transporting a timestamp request to the

and one for sending the timestamp response back to the
client. This command has three main functions: creating a
timestamp request based on a data file, creating a timestamp
response based on a request, verifying if a response
corresponds to a particular request or a data file.

There is no
support for sending the requests/responses automatically
over

The users must send
the requests either by ftp or e-mail.

p._value: Print out a usage message.

_values:
query. For details see "Timestamp Request
generation".

reply. For details see "Timestamp Response
generation".

response. For details see "Timestamp Response
verification".

command can be used for creating and
printing a timestamp request with the following options:

The configuration file to use.
Optional; for a description of the default value, see "

The data file for which the
timestamp request needs to be created. stdin is the default
if neither the

p._value:
It is possible to specify the
message imprint explicitly without the data file. The
imprint must be specified in a hexadecimal format, two
characters per byte, the bytes optionally separated by
colons (e.g. 1A:F6:01:... or 1AF601...). The number of bytes
must match the message digest algorithm in use.
(Optional)

_values:
The message digest to apply to
the data file. Any digest supported by the
(1) command can be used. The default is

The policy that the client
expects the

to use for creating the
timestamp token. Either the dotted

names defined in the config
file can be used. If no policy is requested the

will use its own default policy.
(Optional)

p._value:
No nonce is specified in the
request if this option is given. Otherwise a 64 bit long
pseudo-random none is included in the request. It is
recommended to use nonce to protect against replay-attacks.
(Optional)

format that will be printed into the output file. Useful

A timestamp response (TimeStampResp) consists of a response
status and the timestamp token itself (ContentInfo), if the
token generation was successful. The

command
is for creating a timestamp response or timestamp token
based on a request and printing the response/token in
human-readable format. If

is not specified
the output is always a timestamp response (TimeStampResp),
otherwise it is a timestamp token (ContentInfo).

Optional; for a description of the default value, see "

section containing the settings for the response generation.
If not specified the default

extended key usage must also be critical, otherwise the
certificate is going to be refused. Overrides the

_values:
If this option is specified the
output is human-readable text format instead of

command is for verifying if a timestamp
response or timestamp token is valid and matches a
particular timestamp request or data file. The
command does not use the configuration file.

The response or token must be
verified against file_to_hash. The file is hashed with the
message digest algorithm specified in the token. The

options must not be
specified with this one. (Optional)

The response or token must be
verified against the message digest specified with this
option. The number of bytes must match the message digest
algorithm specified in the token. The

options must not be specified with this
one. (Optional)

options must not be specified with this one.
(Optional)

needs to be verified in

’s

_values:
commands make use of a
configuration file. See

(5) for a general
description of the syntax of the config file. The

names section and it can work without it.
However, the

command needs the config file for
its operation.

When there is a
command line switch equivalent of a variable the switch
always overrides the settings in the config file.

This is the main section and it
specifies the name of another section that contains all the
options for the

command. This default section
can be overridden with the

This specifies a file
containing additional

. Each line of the file should
consist of the numerical form of the object identifier
followed by whitespace then the short name followed by
whitespace and finally the long name. (Optional)

This specifies a section in the
configuration file containing extra object identifiers. Each
line should consist of the short name of the object
identifier followed by

and the numerical form. The
short and long names are the same when this option is used.
(Optional)

At startup the specified file
is loaded into the random number generator, and at exit 256
bytes will be written to it. (Note: Using a

is not necessary anymore, see the
"

p._value:
The name of the file containing
the hexadecimal serial number of the last timestamp response
created. This number is incremented by 1 for each response.
If the file does not exist at the time of response
generation a new file is created with serial number 1.
(Mandatory)

_values:

that will be set as the default for all available
algorithms. The default value is built-in, you can specify
any other engines supported by OpenSSL (e.g. use chil for
the NCipher
A file containing a set of

encoded certificates that need to be
included in the response. The same as the

Signing digest to use. The same

(Mandatory unless specified on the command line)

The default policy to use when

Comma separated list of

and used only if the request explicitly specifies one of

The list of message digest

accepts. At least one
algorithm must be specified. (Mandatory)

The accuracy of the time source
of the

in seconds, milliseconds and
microseconds. E.g. secs:1, millisecs:500, microsecs:100. If
any of the components is missing zero is assumed for that
field. (Optional)

Specifies the maximum number of
digits, which represent the fraction of seconds, that need
to be included in the time field. The trailing zeros must be
removed from the time, so there might actually be fewer
digits, or no fraction of seconds at all. Supported only on

platforms. The maximum value is 6,
default is 0. (Optional)

If this option is yes the
responses generated by this

can always be
ordered, even if the time difference between two responses
is less than the sum of their accuracies. Default is no.
(Optional)

Set this option to yes if the
subject name of the

name field of the response. Default
is no. (Optional)

The SignedData objects created
by the

always contain the certificate
identifier of the signing certificate in a signed attribute
(see

Enhanced Security Services).
If this variable is set to no, only this signing certificate
identifier is included in the SigningCertificate signed
attribute. If this variable is set to yes and the

option is
specified then the certificate identifiers of the chain will
also be included, where the

This option specifies the hash
function to be used to calculate the

’s public key certificate identifier. Default is
sha256. (Optional)

openssl ts

_values:
To create a
timestamp request which includes the

, requests the signer
certificate and nonce, and specifies a policy id (assuming
the tsa_policy1 name is defined in the

Before generating a response a signing certificate must be
created for the

critical extended key usage extension
without any other key usage extensions. You can add this
line to the user certificate section of the config file to
generate a proper certificate;

p._value:
extendedKeyUsage
= critical,timeStamping

_values:
(1) for instructions. The examples below
assume that

is the signing
certificate issued by
is the private key of the

p._value:
To create a
timestamp response for a request:

If you want to
use the settings in the config file you could just
write:

openssl ts
-reply -queryfile design1.tsq -out design1.tsr

To print a
timestamp reply to stdout in human readable format:

openssl ts
-reply -in design1.tsr -text

To create a
timestamp token instead of timestamp response:

openssl ts
-reply -queryfile design1.tsq -out design1_token.der
-token_out

To print a
timestamp token to stdout in human readable format:

openssl ts
-reply -in design1_token.der -token_in -text -token_out

To extract the
timestamp token from a response:

openssl ts
-reply -in design1.tsr -out design1_token.der -token_out

To add
’granted’ status info to a timestamp token
thereby creating a valid response:

openssl ts
-reply -in design1_token.der -token_in -out design1.tsr
To verify a timestamp reply against a request:

To verify a
timestamp reply that includes the certificate chain:

client computes a one-way hash
value for a data file and sends the hash to the

attaches the current date and
time to the received hash value, signs them and sends the
timestamp token back to the client. By creating this token
the

certifies the existence of the
original data file at the time of response generation.

client receives the timestamp
token and verifies the signature on it. It also checks if
the token contains the same hash value that it had sent to
the

though it is quite easy to implement an
automatic e-mail based

server support is provided in the form of a separate apache
module.
The file containing the last serial number of the

is not locked when being read or written.
This is a problem if more than one instance of

(1) is trying to create a timestamp response
at the same time. This is not an issue when using the apache
server module, it does proper locking.

The source code should really be reviewed by somebody
else, too.

More testing is needed, I have done only some basic
tests (see test/testtsa).
